theoryOfChange: Human Rights Watch outlines its approach to bringing about change through a three-step methodology: 'Investigate,' 'Expose,' and 'Change.' Their researchers investigate human rights abuses, corroborate stories, and gather evidence. This information is then widely shared through reports, videos, and social media to shape public debate ('Expose'). Finally, they engage with officials and local groups to advocate for policy changes, enforcement of laws, and justice ('Change'). This structured approach describes how their activities lead to desired outcomes and impact, functioning as an impact framework.

rich_narrative.summary: Founded in <cite id="1">1978</cite>, Human Rights Watch (HRW) is an international non-governmental organization that investigates and reports on human rights abuses globally. The organization operates with a mission to <cite id="1">build just economies and protect fundamental freedoms</cite> through rigorous investigation and strategic advocacy. With <cite id="5">$94,185,941 in total revenue</cite> for the 2023 tax year, HRW maintains a massive global footprint, employing experts, lawyers, and journalists of <cite id="2">70-plus nationalities</cite> to document violations in <cite id="1">all corners of the world</cite>. Their work is structured around systemic change, focusing on specialized areas such as <cite id="2">Environment and Human Rights, Refugees and Migrants Rights, and Economic Justice</cite>. By exposing facts and pressuring those in power, HRW seeks to secure justice for victims and hold abusers accountable. The organization is recognized for its transparency, holding a <cite id="4">91.5/100 overall score from Charity Navigator</cite> and a <cite id="4">Platinum Seal of Transparency from Candid</cite>.
